entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 1 at 4:37PM PST by NWS Eureka CA
entry.summary:
At 436 PM PST, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm over Redway, or near Garberville, moving northeast at 20 mph.
HAZARD...Winds in excess of 40 mph and pea size hail.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around unsecured objects. Minor damage to outdoor objects is possible.
Locations impacted include... Garberville, Redway, Miranda, and Briceland.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Southwestern Humboldt; Southern Humboldt Interior

cap:parameter.value: A STRONG THUNDERSTORM WILL IMPACT SOUTH CENTRAL HUMBOLDT COUNTY THROUGH 500 PM PST

entry.title: Flood Warning issued March 1 at 6:36PM CST by NWS Lake Charles LA
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Texas... Louisiana...
Sabine River Near Deweyville
For the Sabine River...including Burkeville, Bon Wier, Deweyville, Orange...Minor flooding is forecast.
Additional information is available at www.weather.gov.
The next statement will be issued Saturday evening at 645 PM CST.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Sabine River near Deweyville.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 24.0 feet, Minor lowland flooding will occur.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 5:45 PM CST Friday the stage was 24.4 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 5:45 PM CST Friday was 24.4 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to remain steady above flood stage at 24.4 feet. - Flood stage is 24.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Beauregard, LA; Calcasieu, LA; Newton, TX; Orange, TX

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 1 at 4:34PM PST by NWS Hanford CA
entry.summary:
At 433 PM PST, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm near Bootjack, or 13 miles southwest of Yosemite South Entrance, moving northeast at 35 mph.
HAZARD...Wind gusts up to 40 mph and half inch hail.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around unsecured objects. Minor hail damage to vegetation is possible.
Locations impacted include... Yosemite South Entrance, Bootjack, Wawona, Metcalf Gap, Mariposa Grove, Wawona Vistor Center, Jerseydale, Wawona Campground, and Fish Camp.

entry.title: Winter Storm Watch issued March 1 at 6:29PM CST until March 3 at 6:00PM CST by NWS Bismarck ND
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Heavy mixed precipitation possible. There is a 50 to 70 percent chance of snow accumulations exceeding 6 inches. Total ice accumulations of a few hundredths of an inch possible. Winds could gust as high as 40 mph.
* WHERE...Divide, Williams, Burke, Mountrail, Renville, and Ward Counties.
* WHEN...From Saturday evening through Sunday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult. Areas of blowing snow could significantly reduce visibility.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The highest potential for freezing rain is in Ward County Saturday night.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 1 at 5:23PM MST by NWS Riverton WY
entry.summary:
This is a special weather statement from the National Weather Service Office in Riverton.
* WHAT...South to southwest winds 20 to 30 mph, with gusts of 40 to 50 mph.
* WHERE...The Wind River Basin, including Riverton and Lander.
* WHEN...10 AM to 6 PM Saturday.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Motorists should watch for strong cross winds. A cold front will move through the area between 5 PM and 7 PM. Wind gusts of 25 to 40 mph will remain possible through 11 PM.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Wind River Basin; Lander Foothills

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 1 at 5:23PM MST by NWS Riverton WY
entry.summary:
This is a special weather statement from the National Weather Service Office in Riverton.
* WHAT...South to southwest winds of 25 to 35 mph with gusts 50 to 55 mph. Periodic gusts of 60 to 70 mph will be possible in the afternoon. Winds will turn westerly after 5 PM as a cold front moves through the area. Chances for snow will increase during this time, as temperatures drop behind the front. A flash freeze could occur as temperatures quickly drop below freezing through the evening.
* WHERE...Portions of Sweetwater County, including the I-80 corridor.
* WHEN...10 AM to 8 PM Saturday.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Motorists should be alert for slick and snow covered roads and rapid changes in visibility.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Rock Springs and Green River; Flaming Gorge; East Sweetwater County

cap:parameter.value: Strong to high winds and snow will occur Saturday

entry.title: Flood Watch issued March 1 at 4:21PM PST until March 2 at 4:00AM PST by NWS Medford OR
entry.summary:
...The Flood Watch is extended for the following rivers in Oregon...
Coquille River at Coquille affecting South Central Oregon Coast zone.
.Moderate precipitation is expected today and tonight, then light to moderate precipitation follows this weekend.
* WHAT...Flooding is possible. The river has risen to bankfull and is forecast to hold just below flood stage. However, if heavier precipitation arrives that exceeds current forecast amounts, this could push the river to flood stage.
* WHERE...Coquille River at Coquille.
* WHEN...Until late tonight.
* IMPACTS...At 20.0 feet, Expect some slight pasture flooding in low-lying areas along and near the Coquille River. Cattle and other farm animals which graze on the floodplain may be impacted.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 3:45 PM PST Friday the stage was 20.3 feet. - Forecast...Flood stage may be reached based on the latest forecast information. - Flood stage is 21.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: South Central Oregon Coast

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WATCH NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL LATE TONIGHT

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued March 1 at 6:19PM CST until March 2 at 8:00PM CST by NWS Dodge City KS
entry.summary:
...Risk of Wildfire Spread Saturday and Sunday Afternoons...
...FIRE WEATHER WATCH REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM SUNDAY AFTERNOON THROUGH SUNDAY EVENING FOR WIND AND LOW RELATIVE HUMIDITY.
* AFFECTED AREA...Fire Weather Zone 074 Stanton, Fire Weather Zone 075 Grant, Fire Weather Zone 076 Haskell, Fire Weather Zone 077 Gray, Fire Weather Zone 078 Ford, Fire Weather Zone 080 Kiowa, Fire Weather Zone 084 Morton, Fire Weather Zone 085 Stevens, Fire Weather Zone 086 Seward, Fire Weather Zone 087 Meade, Fire Weather Zone 088 Clark and Fire Weather Zone 089 Comanche.
* WINDS...Southwest 20 to 30 mph with gusts up to 40 mph.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...As low as 8 percent.
* IMPACTS...Widespread dormant fuels will be receptive of ignition, and will pose a risk of rapid wildfire spread should an ignition occur. Any fires may burn out of control quickly. Any outdoor burning is strongly discouraged.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Stanton; Grant; Haskell; Gray; Ford; Kiowa; Morton; Stevens; Seward; Meade; Clark; Comanche

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 1 at 4:17PM PST by NWS Spokane WA
entry.summary:
At 414 PM PST, an area of heavy snow was located near Spokane moving north at 30 mph. Accumulations will be minimal below 2300 feet. Up to an inch of snow is posssible above 2300 feet.
Locations impacted include... Spokane, Spokane Valley, Liberty Lake, Airway Heights, Nine Mile Falls, Deer Park, Newport, Millwood, Otis Orchards-East Farms, Fairwood, Suncrest, Fairchild AFB, Otis Orchards, Green Acres, Trentwood, Country Homes, Town And Country, Chattaroy, Dishman, and Mead.
This includes the following highways... Interstate 90 in Washington between mile markers 275 and 299.
U.S. Highway 2 in Washington between mile markers 263 and 334. U.S. Highway 195 in Washington between mile markers 92 and 95. U.S. Highway 395 in Washington between mile markers 165 and 203.
Visibilities will drop quickly to less than a mile in this area of heavy snow.
Icy roads are possible tonight as the snow melts on the roads then refreezes.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Spokane Area; Northeast Mountains

entry.title: Avalanche Watch issued March 1 at 4:42PM MST by NWS Denver CO
entry.summary:
AVABOU
THE FOLLOWING MESSAGE IS TRANSMITTED AT THE REQUEST OF THE COLORADO AVALANCHE INFORMATION CENTER.
...AVALANCHE WATCH IN EFFECT FOR SUNDAY 5 AM THROUGH SUNDAY 11 PM...
*WHAT...Heavy snow and strong winds will result in very dangerous avalanche conditions and HIGH (Level 4 of 5) avalanche danger on Sunday
*WHERE...The Park Range, Flat Tops, Grand Mesa, West Elk and Elk Mountains, Ruby Range, Ragged Range, Gore Range, Northern and Cenrtal Sawatch Range
*WHEN...Beginning Sunday morning and lasting through Sunday
*IMPACTS...Large and dangerous avalanches will be very easy to trigger in many places. Avalanches will run naturally.
*PRECAUTION/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...Travel in backcountry avalanche terrain is not recommended in the mentioned areas on Sunday. Avoid travel on and under slopes steeper than about 30 degrees. You can find more detailed information at colorado.gov/avalanche

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 1 at 5:32PM CST by NWS Grand Forks ND
entry.summary:
A mix of freezing rain (less than 0.05") and snow (less than half an inch) tonight into Saturday morning could lead to slick travel across the region.
A period of light mixed precipitation of freezing rain and snow will move into portions of the Devils Lake Basin and northern Red River Valley Saturday into Saturday night. Amounts are expected to remain very light Saturday night but could bring some minor travel impacts. A stronger round of precipitation will move in Sunday, starting with rain and freezing rain and then changing over to snow. There will be a 40 percent change for a light glaze of ice over portions of the Devils Lake Basin. Probabilities for over 2 inches of snow will range from 20 percent in the northern Red River Valley to 60 percent in northwestern Towner county. In addition to falling snow, there is the potential for some blowing snow on Sunday evening. While all of the winter impacts may not exactly line up for warning level conditions, there is high probability for at least minor winter impacts this weekend.
Check road conditions... By Phone: call 511 Website for North Dakota: travel.dot.nd.gov Website for Minnesota: 511mn.org
entry.cap:areaDesc: West Polk; Kittson; Roseau; West Marshall; East Marshall; Towner; Cavalier; Pembina; Benson; Ramsey; Eastern Walsh County; Eddy; Nelson; Grand Forks; Griggs; Steele; Traill; Western Walsh County

.Northerly outflow winds will generate 20 mph sustained wind speeds for the Klondike Highway. These winds combined with temperatures as low as 9 below zero will cause wind chills to 35 below zero.
* WHAT...Very cold wind chills expected. Wind chills as low as 35 below zero.
* WHERE...Klondike Highway.

entry.title: Flood Warning issued March 1 at 6:13PM EST until March 2 at 2:34AM EST by NWS Peachtree City GA
entry.summary:
...The National Weather Service in Peachtree City GA has issued a Flood Warning for the following rivers in Georgia...
Big Creek at GA 9 near Cumming affecting Forsyth County.
For the Big Creek...including Cumming...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Big Creek at GA 9 near Cumming.
* WHEN...From this evening to just after midnight tonight.
* IMPACTS...At 6 feet, Flood stage is reached. Minor flooding will expand into the natural flood plain of the creek upstream and downstream from the gage at Atlanta Highway or Georgia Highway 9. Large portions of the sidewalk and boardwalk of the Big Creek Greenway will begin to flood. The areas under the Georgia 400 Highway and McFarland Road will be covered with around one foot of water. A portion of the sidewalk under Majors Road will be covered with around two feet of water.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 5:45 PM EST Friday the stage was 6 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage tonight. - Flood stage is 6 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

Interstate 77 between mile markers 0 and 24. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

* WHAT...For the Winter Storm Warning, heavy snow. Additional snow accumulations of 5 to 14 inches. Winds gusting as high as 50 mph over exposed terrain. For the Winter Weather Advisory above 4500 feet, snow expected. Total snow accumulations of 6 to 9 inches. Winds gusting as high as 35 mph.
* WHERE...South Central Siskiyou County and North Central and Southeast Siskiyou County. This includes Snowman's Summit and Dead Horse Summit on highway 89.
* WHEN...For the Winter Storm Warning, until 10 AM PST Saturday. For the Winter Weather Advisory, from 10 AM Saturday to 4 PM PST Sunday.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult to impossible. Widespread blowing snow could significantly reduce visibility. Gusty winds could bring down tree branches.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Snow levels will be lowest on Saturday, rise slightly Sunday, and increase up to 3000 feet on Monday.
* View the hazard area in detail at https://www.wrh.noaa.gov/map/?wfo=mfr
entry.cap:areaDesc: South Central Siskiyou County; North Central and Southeast Siskiyou County

entry.title: Blizzard Warning issued March 1 at 2:20PM PST until March 3 at 4:00AM PST by NWS Reno NV
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Blizzard conditions likely, particularly through Saturday morning. There is a 10-20% chance of thunderstorms along the crest through this evening with snowfall rates of 4 to 6 inches per hour at times. Snow accumulations of 2 to 5 feet for Plumas, Sierra and western Lassen counties, 6 to 18 inches along Highway 395 in Lassen County. Localized amounts of 5 to 10 feet near Lassen Park, Yuba Pass, and Lake Davis. Winds gusting as high as 70 mph with significant drifting of snow.
* WHERE...Lassen-Eastern Plumas-Eastern Sierra Counties.
* WHEN...Until 4 AM PST Sunday.
* IMPACTS...Whiteout conditions with near zero visibility at times due to blowing snow. The strong winds and weight of snow on tree limbs may down power lines and could cause sporadic power outages. Travel will be treacherous and potentially life-threatening.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Lassen-Eastern Plumas-Eastern Sierra Counties

cap:parameter.value: BLIZZARD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 4 AM PST SUNDAY

entry.title: Winter Storm Warning issued March 1 at 2:05PM PST until March 3 at 10:00AM PST by NWS Los Angeles/Oxnard CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Strong winds and heavy snow expected. Total snow accumulations 7 to 14 inches for elevations above 6,000 feet, and 2 to 6 inches between 5,000 and 6,000 feet. Peak southwest winds of 25 to 40 mph with gusts to 65 mph expected, strongest Saturday.
* WHERE...Eastern San Gabriel Mountains.
* WHEN...From 6 PM this evening to 10 AM PST Sunday.
* IMPACTS...Very strong winds could cause extensive damage including downed trees and power outages. Travel could be very difficult to impossible. There will be considerable blowing and drifting snow, with visibilities down to near zero at times.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Accumulating snow will be confined to elevations above 5000 feet for most of the event, but light accumulations are possible down to 4000 feet Saturday Night into Sunday.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Eastern San Gabriel Mountains

entry.summary:

* WHERE...Northern Ventura County Mountains.
* WHEN...Until 10 AM PST Sunday.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Accumulating snow will be confined to elevations above 5000 feet for most of the event, but light accumulations are possible down to 4000 feet Saturday Night into Sunday.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Northern Ventura County Mountains

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued March 1 at 2:39PM MST until March 2 at 7:00PM MST by NWS Albuquerque NM
entry.summary:
...RED FLAG WARNING IN EFFECT FOR THE SANDIA/MANZANO MOUNTAINS AND NORTHEAST AND EAST CENTRAL NM FROM 11 AM TO 7 PM MST SATURDAY DUE TO STRONG WINDS, LOW HUMIDITY, AND ABOVE NORMAL TEMPERATURES...
...RED FLAG WARNING IN EFFECT FOR NORTHEAST AND EAST CENTRAL NM SUNDAY DUE TO STRONG WINDS, LOW HUMIDITY, AND ABOVE NORMAL TEMPERATURES...
.Southwest winds will strengthen Saturday across eastern New Mexico as an upper level storm system approaches from the Great Basin. The combination of strong winds, single digit humidity, and above normal temperatures will increase the risk for critical fire weather conditions. Southwest to west winds will strengthen even further into Sunday.
* AREA AND TIMING...Sandia and Manzano Mountains (Zone 124) from 11 AM to 7 PM MST Saturday.
* 20 FOOT WINDS...Southwest 25 to 35 mph with gusts up to 45 mph.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...10 to 14 percent.
* IMPACTS...Any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly. Outdoor burning is not recommended.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Sandia and Manzano Mountains

entry.title: Blizzard Warning issued March 1 at 1:37PM PST until March 3 at 10:00AM PST by NWS Sacramento CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Extremely dangerous to impossible travel from blizzard conditions. Total snow accumulations of 5 to 10 feet above 5000 feet, local amounts of 12 feet or more over peaks, with 1 to 4 feet above 3000 feet through Sunday morning. Minor accumulations down to around 2000 feet. Winds gusting as high as 75 mph or higher.
* WHERE...West Slope Northern Sierra Nevada, Northeast Foothills, Motherlode, and Western Plumas County/Lassen Park above 2000 feet. Including Interstate 80 and Highway 50.
* WHEN...Until 10 AM PST Sunday.
* IMPACTS...Extremely dangerous to impossible travel conditions with extended road closures likely. Widespread blowing snow will create blizzard conditions with white-out conditions and near zero visibility. Very strong winds, combined with heavy snow could cause extensive tree damage and extended power outages.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Snow levels 4000 to 5000 feet, lowering to around 2000 feet by Saturday. Intense snow rates of 2 to 4 inches per hour at times. Blizzard conditions at times, especially through Saturday when snowfall is heaviest.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 1 at 3:06PM CST by NWS Grand Forks ND
entry.summary:
A period of light mixed precipitation of freezing rain and snow will move into portions of the Devils Lake Basin and northern Red River Valley Saturday into Saturday night. Amounts are expected to remain very light Saturday night but could bring some minor travel impacts. A stronger round of precipitation will move in Sunday, starting with rain and freezing rain and then changing over to snow. There will be a 40 percent change for a light glaze of ice over portions of the Devils Lake Basin. Probabilities for over 2 inches of snow will range from 20 percent in the northern Red River Valley to 60 percent in northwestern Towner county. In addition to falling snow, there is the potential for some blowing snow on Sunday evening. While all of the winter impacts may not exactly line up for warning level conditions, there is high probability for at least minor winter impacts this weekend.
Check road conditions... By Phone: call 511 Website for North Dakota: travel.dot.nd.gov Website for Minnesota: 511mn.org
entry.cap:areaDesc: Kittson; West Marshall; Towner; Cavalier; Pembina; Benson; Ramsey; Eastern Walsh County; Eddy; Nelson; Western Walsh County

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued March 1 at 12:26PM PST until March 1 at 10:00PM PST by NWS Eureka CA
entry.summary:
...STRONG WINTER STORM THROUGH SUNDAY NIGHT...
.A strong winter storm will continue to impact the area through the weekend. Snow levels will rapidly drop Friday night between 500 and 1500 feet. This will allow for heavy snow of 1 to 2 feet on high mountain passes and lighter snow of 4 to 8 inches in low elevation valleys. Additional snow showers will continue through Sunday.
* WHAT...For the Winter Weather Advisory for elevations above 2000 feet, wet snow expected. Total snow accumulations of 3 to 6 inches on high passes. Winds gusting as high as 45 mph on high ridges. For the Winter Storm Warning for elevations above 1500 feet, heavy snow expected. Total snow accumulations between 8 and 15 inches on high passes. Winds gusting as high as 45 mph on high ridges.
* WHERE...Southwestern Humboldt.
* WHEN...For the Winter Weather Advisory, until 10 PM PST this evening. For the Winter Storm Warning, from 10 PM this evening to 10 AM PST Sunday.
* IMPACTS...Visibilities may drop below 1/4 mile due to falling and blowing snow. The strong winds and weight of snow on tree limbs may down power lines and could cause sporadic power outages. Travel could be very difficult. Strong winds could cause extensive damage to trees and power lines. Roads, and especially bridges and overpasses, will likely become slick and hazardous.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Southwestern Humboldt

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 1 at 2:10PM CST by NWS Bismarck ND
entry.summary:
Low to medium chances for light freezing rain will develop across central and southern North Dakota tonight, with the highest probabilities of a light glaze of ice along and north of Interstate 94. The chance of freezing rain will decrease during the day Saturday, with afternoon temperatures rising above freezing. Higher chances for freezing rain will then impact the same areas Saturday evening through early Sunday morning. Ice accumulations are expected to remain under one tenth of an inch, but it only takes a light glaze to create very slippery conditions.
If you have travel plans this weekend, be sure to check the latest forecast information and road conditions.

entry.summary:
...The National Weather Service in Peachtree City GA has issued a Flood Warning for the following rivers in Georgia...
Big Creek near Alpharetta affecting Fulton and Forsyth Counties.
For the Big Creek...including Cumming, Alpharetta, Roswell...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Big Creek near Alpharetta.
* WHEN...From late tonight to Sunday morning.
* IMPACTS...At 7 feet, Flood Stage is reached. Minor flooding of woodlands and fields begin along the creek between Cumming in Forsyth County...to Alpharetta and Roswell in North Fulton County. Flooding starts to effect portions of The Big Creek Greenway near Alpharetta and some portions may become closed with around one foot of water...especially upstream and downstream from the gage on Kimball Bridge Road and near Rock Mill Park. Portions of the YMCA Campground off Preston Ridge Road will begin to flood.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1:15 PM EST Friday the stage was 5.1 feet and rising. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage just after midnight tonight to a crest of 7.3 feet early tomorrow afternoon. It will then fall below flood stage early Sunday morning. - Flood stage is 7 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Forsyth, GA; Fulton, GA

entry.title: High Surf Advisory issued March 1 at 9:57AM PST until March 4 at 9:00AM PST by NWS Los Angeles/Oxnard CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Large breaking waves of 4 to 7 feet with dangerous rip currents. Highest surf, along with possible very minor coastal flooding, for west facing beaches.
* WHERE...Catalina and Santa Barbara Islands, Malibu Coast and Los Angeles County Beaches.
* WHEN...From 3 PM Saturday to 9 AM PST Monday.
* IMPACTS...There is an increased risk for ocean drowning. Rip currents can pull swimmers and surfers out to sea. Large breaking waves can cause injury, wash people off beaches and rocks, and capsize small boats near shore. Very minor flooding of sea water is possible, around the time of high tide, over vulnerable low- lying coastal areas such as parking lots, beaches, and walkways. Significant damage to roads or structures is NOT expected.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...High tides will occur overnight between Midnight and 2 AM, peaking around 5 feet.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Catalina and Santa Barbara Islands; Malibu Coast; Los Angeles County Beaches

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued March 1 at 10:50AM MST by NWS Phoenix AZ
entry.summary:
The Imperial County APCD has issued an air quality alert due to increased particulate matter from blowing dust. The air quality alert is in effect Saturday, March 2, 2024 and Sunday, March 3, 2024.
In areas directly impacted by high levels of windblown dust, limit your exposure by remaining indoors with windows and doors closed and avoiding vigorous physical activity. Run your air conditioner or an air purifier. If temperatures allow, avoid using whole house fans or swamp coolers that bring in outside air.
Exposure to high particle pollution levels can cause serious health problems, including asthma attacks, heart and lung disease symptoms, and increased risk of respiratory infections. People with heart or lung diseases should follow their doctor's advice for dealing with episodes of unhealthy air quality. Children, older adults, and people with respiratory or heart disease should avoid prolonged exposure and strenuous activities when particle pollution levels are high.
To help minimize outdoor particulate levels: Carpool, telecommute, reduce trips, or take public transportation Slow down if driving on dirt roads Stabilize loose soils
Levels of particulate matter can vary hour by hour and by location depending on wind conditions.
To view current and forecast air quality within Imperial County visit the Imperial County Air Quality website at http://www.imperialvalleyair.org/ or follow ICAPCD on Twitter, facebook or Instagram (@county_air).
entry.cap:areaDesc: Imperial County Southwest; Imperial County West; Imperial Valley

cap:parameter.value: AIR QUALITY ALERT DUE TO ELEVATED PARTICULATE MATTER LEVELS FROM WINDBLOWN DUST

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 1 at 9:31AM PST by NWS Spokane WA
entry.summary: Widely scattered snow showers will develop this afternoon into the early evening hours today. Snow showers will be capable of producing bursts of heavy snow and gusty winds between 20 to 30 mph. Organized showers may produce snow squalls with visibility rapidly dropping down to one-half mile or less. Intense snow showers may also drop road surface temperatures down to below freezing with icy conditions rapidly developing, especially around the time of the evening commute. Remain alert to the latest weather and travel conditions and keep an eye out for snow squall warnings. If caught in a snow squall, remember to reduce speeds and to turn on headlights and hazard lights.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 1 at 5:35AM AKST by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
A strong front will bring a combination of snow, wind, and blowing snow to much of the west coast starting Saturday. The worst conditions will be Saturday evening near the Yukon Delta and St. Lawrence Island where Winter Storm Watches for possible blizzard conditions are in effect. Southeast winds will ramp up from Shishmaref to Kotzebue to Point Hope Saturday night, bringing a brief period of very cold wind chills followed by blowing snow, then light snowfall and continued wind and blowing snow on Sunday. Blizzard conditions are possible and winds may gust as high as 50 mph.
A second front will arrive to the Yukon Delta late Sunday, bringing heavier snowfall and SE winds gusting to 40 mph. Uncertainty still exists with this system, but it may bring heavier snowfall Monday and Tuesday as well, especially south of the Bering Strait.
Residents are encouraged to stay up to date with the latest forecast at www.weather.gov/fairbanks and be prepared for upcoming winter weather.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Kivalina and Red Dog Dock; Lower Kobuk Valley; Baldwin Peninsula; Northern Seward Peninsula; Shishmaref; Bering Strait Coast; Southern Seward Peninsula Coast; Interior Seward Peninsula; Eastern Norton Sound and Nulato Hills

cap:parameter.value: Series of Fronts To Bring Snow, Wind, and Blowing Snow Starting Saturday

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued March 1 at 3:00AM EST until March 2 at 3:00AM EST by NWS Melbourne FL
entry.summary:
* WHAT...A northward flowing longshore current with a Moderate risk of dangerous rip currents exists in the surf zone today.
* WHERE...Beaches of Volusia, Brevard, Indian River, Saint Lucie and Martin counties.
* WHEN...Through late tonight.
* IMPACTS...Breezy southerly winds will produce a moderate northward flowing longshore current today, which can push swimmers into deeper water unexpectedly, and make them more susceptible to dangerous rip currents.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Coastal Volusia; Coastal Indian River; Coastal St. Lucie; Coastal Martin; Mainland Northern Brevard; Northern Brevard Barrier Islands; Mainland Southern Brevard; Southern Brevard Barrier Islands

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued February 29 at 10:01PM AKST by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
A very cold airmass over Interior Alaska and will last into this weekend. Low temperatures will be in the 20s and 30s below, with a few areas in the 40s below, through the weekend. Highs will be zero to 10 below.
Slightly warmer temperatures are expected to move over the Interior Sunday night and Monday.
